briefTitle: Study Evaluating Pantoprazole Sodium Enteric-Coated Spheroid Suspension In Infants With Presumed GERD

armGroups.label: Low dose
interventionNames: Drug: pantoprazole sodium enteric-coated spheroid suspension

armGroups.label: High dose
interventionNames: Drug: pantoprazole sodium enteric-coated spheroid suspension

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Greater than 44 weeks beyond neonatal period but less than 12 months
* Presumptive diagnosis of GERD
* Weight greater than 2.5 kg but less than 15 kg

Exclusion Criteria:

* History of gastrointestinal (GI) disorders, ie, unrepaired tracheal esophageal fistula, GI malabsorption
* Clinically significant medical or surgical abnormalities

outcomeMeasures.title: Peak Concentration (Cmax)
outcomeMeasures.description: Pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters, including peak plasma concentration, were determined following a single oral dose of pantoprazole

outcomeMeasures.title: Time to Peak Concentration (Tmax) Profile
outcomeMeasures.description: Pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters, including time to peak plasma concentration, were determined following a single oral dose of pantoprazole.

outcomeMeasures.title: Disposition Half-life
outcomeMeasures.description: Pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters, including the terminal-phase disposition half-life, were determined following a single oral dose of pantoprazole. Half-life is the time required for half the quantity of absorbed drug to be metabolized or eliminated by normal biological processes.

outcomeMeasures.title: Area Under the Concentration-time Curve (AUC)
outcomeMeasures.description: Pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters, including AUC, were determined following a single oral dose of pantoprazole. AUC is a measure of the plasma concentration of the drug over time. It is used to characterize drug absorption.

outcomeMeasures.title: Apparent Oral Clearance (CL/F)
outcomeMeasures.description: Pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters, including apparent oral clearance, were determined following a single oral dose of pantoprazole. Clearance of a drug is a measure of the rate at which a drug is metabolized or eliminated by normal biological processes. Clearance obtained after oral dose (apparent oral clearance) is influenced by the fraction of the dose absorbed.

outcomeMeasures.title: Pantoprazole Plasma Concentration After Multiple-Dose Oral Administration
outcomeMeasures.description: Plasma concentration of pantoprazole after multiple doses was measured to see if there was any accumulation of the drug.

outcomeMeasures.title: Intragastric pH
outcomeMeasures.description: Intragastric pH is a method for evaluating gastric acidity scaled 0-9. A lower pH means more acidity. A longer duration of esophageal mucosa exposure to a gastric refluxate with a pH \<4.0 correlates with more severe mucosal injury in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

outcomeMeasures.title: Median Intragastric pH
outcomeMeasures.description: Intragastric pH is a method for evaluating gastric acidity scaled 0-9. A lower pH means more acidity. A longer duration of esophageal mucosa exposure to a gastric refluxate with a pH \<4.0 correlates with more severe mucosal injury in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

outcomeMeasures.title: Percentage of Time Intragastric pH Was >4
outcomeMeasures.description: Intragastric pH is a method for evaluating gastric acidity. A lower pH means more acidity. A longer duration of esophageal mucosa exposure to a gastric refluxate with a pH \<4.0 correlates with more severe mucosal injury in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

outcomeMeasures.title: Mean Intraesophageal pH
outcomeMeasures.description: Intraesophagel pH is a method for evaluating acidity of gastric refluxate scaled 0-9. A lower pH means more acidity. A longer duration of esophageal mucosa exposure to a gastric refluxate with a pH \<4.0 correlates with more severe mucosal injury in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

outcomeMeasures.title: Median Intraesophageal pH
outcomeMeasures.description: Intraesophagel pH is a method for evaluating acidity of gastric refluxate scaled 0-9. A lower pH means more acidity. A longer duration of esophageal mucosa exposure to a gastric refluxate with a pH \<4.0 correlates with more severe mucosal injury in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

outcomeMeasures.title: Percentage of Time That Intraesophageal pH Was <4
outcomeMeasures.description: Intraesophagel pH is a method for evaluating acidity of gastric refluxate. A lower pH means more acidity. A longer duration of esophageal mucosa exposure to a gastric refluxate with a pH \<4.0 correlates with more severe mucosal injury in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

outcomeMeasures.title: Normalized Area of Gastric Hydrogen Ion Activity Over Time
outcomeMeasures.description: Normalized Area of Gastric Hydrogen Ion Activity Over Time is a measure of the area under the curve of the gastric hydrogen ion activity over time, which is normalized for a 24-hour period.

outcomeMeasures.title: Normalized Area of Esophageal Hydrogen Ion Activity Over Time
outcomeMeasures.description: Normalized Area of Esophageal Hydrogen Ion Activity Over Time is a measure of the area under the curve of the esophageal hydrogen ion activity over time, which is normalized for a 24-hour period.
